question: 上がる
sourceAnswer: to:{rise/go-up/come-up/ascend/be-raised} | to:{enter-(esp.-from-outdoors)/come-in/go-in} | to:{enter-(a-school)/advance-to-the-next-grade} | to:{get-out-(of-water)/come-ashore} | to:increase | to:{improve/make-progress} | to:{be-promoted/advance} | to-be:made-(of-profit,-etc.) | to:occur-(esp.-of-a-favourable-result) | to-be:adequate-(to-cover-expenses,-etc.) | to-be:{finished/done/over} | (of-rain)-to-stop/to-lift | to:{stop-(working-properly)/cut-out/give-out/die} | to:win-(in-a-card-game,-etc.) | to-be:arrested | to:turn-up-(of-evidence,-etc.) | to-be:deep-fried | to-be:spoken-loudly | to:{get-nervous/get-stage-fright} | to-be:offered-(to-the-gods,-etc.) | to:{go/visit} | to:{eat/drink} | to-be:listed-(as-a-candidate) | to:serve-(in-one's-master's-home) | to:go-north | to{?}{be-complete/finish}
userAnswer: to: rise | come-in | enter(school) | come-ashore | improve | be-promoted ...
activeAnswer: to: rise | come-in | enter(school) | come-ashore | improve | be-promoted ...
sourceMnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means <kanji>above</kanji> so this means something rises. For example: A fever goes up. The sun rises. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go up</vocabulary>.

Be careful not to confuse this with its transitive buddy <ja>上げる</ja>, which means "to lift something" or "to raise something." With that other verb, someone is doing the lifting, it's not happening by itself like it is here.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading, which also happens to be a reading you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. Let's use a mnemonic for the kun'yomi reading now, though. You have to remember at least the <ja>あ</ja> part to read it.

You know that this word means <vocabulary>to go up</vocabulary>. Imagine something just rising on its own, like a floating tree or something. What would you say? Probably a "surprised" sound. Maybe you'd scream "<ja><reading>あ</reading></ja>!" when you saw this floating tree.

If you need help remembering the hiragana part, imagine that it's a girl rising up and you scream "<reading>Ah! Girl!</reading>"(<ja>あがる</ja>).
